title: Do power meters work indoors (or how can I simulate power indoors)?

comments.body:
I apologize in advance if this information is covered in another (or multiple) thread(s), but I have a few questions re: training with power indoors. 

Basically, I want to begin training with power but I can\'t afford both a Wahoo Kickr (or similar) as well as a power meter for my bike. Thus, I have a few questions for everyone who is far more knowledgeable than I. 

1. Would a crank-based power meter (e.g., Power2Max) work indoors on a CyleOps Fluid trainer? 
2. Do any power meters work indoors on a CycleOps Fluid trainer? 
3. Is there a trainer (or quasi roller system) for $500 or less that would allow me to use a power meter (assuming I sold the CycleOps)? 
4. If no power meter will work on a trainer, what accessories do I need to buy in order to simulate power indoors? 

And the "catch-all" question: 

5. If I were to buy a power2max or other crank-based power meter, what option would you recommend for training with power indoors? 

I suppose I should apologize in the event any (or all) of the above questions are completely stupid. 

Thanks!
